thoughts.a: The input and output grids are the same size. The input grid is a mostly black color background with a large diagonally shaped gray object. Above the gray object there is also a single line of three tiles, each of which is a different color. The tile colors in the line are blue, green, and yellow. The output grid looks very similar in structure to the input grid but the gray object has changed to a multi-colored object. The gray object has been colored with a pattern of blue, green, and yellow tiles. This diagonally shaped object now looks like a bunch of 3x3 tile squares that have been stacked on top of each other in a diagonal fashion, allowing some of the tiles of the previous square layers to be partially seen. For example, the back-most layer can be thought of as a blue square that has been partially covered up by a green square, which has been partially covered up by a yellow square, and so on, repeating the colors until the final front-most square layer in the stack, which in this case is fully exposed with a full 3x3 yellow square. We notice that the order of the colors of the square layers matches the left to right order of the colors of the short line: blue, green, and then yellow. This line in the input grid acts as indicator tiles, telling us how to construct the colored pattern within the gray object. Thus the hypothesis is the following. The input grid will be mostly a background color, probably black, and will contain a large diagonally shaped gray object. There will also be a single tile tall horizontal line which acts as indicator tiles to establish the pattern we need to use in the output grid. In order to construct the output grid, the gray object should be colored with a pattern according to the colors from left to right in the indicator color tile line. This pattern is made by acting like the gray object is a diagonal stack of square layers, with each square layer partially covering the next one. The first color in the indicator line on the left corresponds to the back-most square, or bottom layer, in the stack. In this case, that color was blue. Then the square layers are colored according to the left to right indicator colors, repeating when necessary. The final square layer will be fully visible in the front-most layer, at the top of the stack. Note that the top and bottom here do not refer to the grid orientation top or bottom, but rather how this stack might be thought of in 3D space if these squares were instead aligned perfectly on top of each other. The rest of the output grid is exactly the same as the input grid. The only thing that has changed is the colors of the gray object.
thoughts.b: The input grid contains a black color background and a large diagonally shaped gray object. There is also a horizontal line with four different colors, in order from left to right, blue, red, green, and aqua. According to the hypothesis, in order to construct the output grid, we need to copy over the input grid as is and then color the gray object according to the pattern of colors established by the indicator line. In this case, the pattern starts with blue, then red, then green, then aqua, and then will repeat as necessary. The gray object can be thought of as a stack of 4x4 tile squares that are stacked on top of each other but slightly diagonally offset such that each square layer only partially covers up the layer underneath it. In order to properly apply the colored pattern, we need to apply the first color, blue, to the back-most square layer in the stack, which in this case would correspond to the 4x4 square in the spatial top left part of the output grid. However, almost all of that blue square will be covered by the next square layer, red, and repeating with green, and aqua until we hit the final, top-most 4x4 square of aqua is fully uncovered. Because this is exactly what we see in the output grid, the hypothesis holds.
thoughts.c: The input grid contains a black color background and two large diagonally shaped gray objects There is also a horizontal line with three different colors and the order from left to right red, aqua, and green. According to the hypothesis, in order to construct the output grid, we need to copy over the input grid as is, and then color each of the gray objects according to the pattern of colors established by the multi-colored indicator line. Each gray object can be thought of as a stack of 4x4 tile squares that are stacked on top of each other but slightly diagonally offset such that each square layer only partially covers up the layer underneath it. In this case, we have two such gray objects, and thus we should handle each object independently, one after the other. In order to properly apply the colored pattern established by the indicator line, we need to apply the first color, red, to the backmost square layer in the stack, which in this case would correspond to the 4x4 squares in the spatial topmost part of the output grid for both of the gray objects. However, almost all of that red square will be covered by the next square layer, aqua, and repeating with green and then back to red and so on until the entire gray object has been colored. Because one gray object can be thought of as 6 total square layers, and the other can be thought of as 3 total square layers, each of the now colored objects in the output grid will have a green 4x4 tile square fully visible as the top-most square layer of each object. Because this is exactly what we see in the output grid, the hypothesis holds. Additionally, when given multiple gray digonally shaped objects, we know we need to color all of them in the appropriate way.
thoughts.d: We apply the hypothesis here. The input grid contains a black color background and three large diagonally shaped gray objects. There is also a horizontal line with four different colors and the order from left to right of these colors are blue, green, yellow, and red. According to the hypothesis, in order to construct the output grid, we need to copy over the input grid as is and then color each of the gray objects according to the pattern of colors established by the multicolored indicator line in the input grid. In this case, each gray object can be thought of as a stack of 5x5 tile squares that are stacked on top of each other but slightly diagonally offset such that each square layer only partically covers up the layer underneath it. In this case, we have three such gray objects, and thus we should handle each object independently, one after the other. In order to properly apply the colored pattern established by the indicator line, we need to apply the first color, blue, to the back-most square layer in the stack. Almost all of that blue layer will be covered up by a green square layer, which will then be mostly covered up by yellow, and then red, and then so on until each gray object has been fully changed into a multi-colored object. Because all the gray objects can be thought of as stacks of either 4 or 8 square layers, the top-most square layer in all the stacks will be the last color of the four colors present in the indicator tile line, red. Thus, for each object, there should be a red 5x5 tile square fully visible as part of the top-most square layer of the stack.
